Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: What is Behind the Worldwide Success of Pseudomonas Syringae Pv. Tomato: a Comparative Evolutionary Genomics investigation
Award.AbstractNarration: The ability of organisms to adapt to new niches becomes a primary concern to our society when it involves the specialization of pathogens to humans, farm animals or crops. Little is known about how plant pathogens, which were adapted to natural mixed-plant communities in pre-agricultural times, evolved into today's highly aggressive pathogens of crops cultivated in monoculture. To fill this void, this project aims at identifying the molecular evolutionary mechanisms that allow pathogens to specialize to specific plant species and to become more aggressive. The bacterial plant pathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato (the cause of bacterial speck disease of tomato worldwide) and closely related bacteria, will be the focus of this project. A multidisciplinary approach of comparative evolutionary genomics, population genetics, and microbial genetics will be applied leveraging the latest advances in biological sciences and computer sciences. Research and education will be integrated through the development and teaching of an undergraduate course in 'Microbial Genomics and Forensics' and the creation of internship opportunities for undergraduates in the principal investigator's lab and in the biotechnology industry. It is anticipated that this project will uncover genomic changes that occurred in P. syringae pv. tomato during its evolution since the advent of agriculture and that have led to its current aggressiveness and worldwide distribution. Results from this research are expected to constitute the basis for the development of new hypotheses on the evolution of bacterial pathogens in general and to be instrumental in future breeding and engineering of disease resistant crops. Easy access to obtained results will be provided through a web-accessible database. The research in the principal investigator's lab, the undergraduate course and the collaboration with industry will not only attract students to research and provide advanced training, but also give students of underrepresented groups the opportunity to jump-start their professional careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several detrimental bacterial plant diseases have recently spread to new geographic areas. For example, citrus greening and citrus canker spread to Florida and are putting the entire Florida orange industry at risk of extinction. Moreover, previously completely unknown diseases have emerged for the first time. For example canker of kiwifruit was first described in the 1980s and is now threatening kiwifruit production all of over the world. In these and many other cases we do not know where and when these diseases first emerged, which the reservoirs are from which they emerged, and which routes they took to spread around the world. We neither know how the pathogens that cause these diseases became the highly virulent and host-specific pathogens they are today.

In this project we started answering these questions for the tomato pathogen Pseudomonas syringae pv. tomato (Pto), which causes bacterial speck disease of tomato, a disease that severely reduces tomato yield and quality. We found that Pto is very closely related to many different bacteria that exist in previously unsuspected environments connected by the water cycle: rain and snow, alpine meadows, rivers, and lakes. This suggests that these environments might present some of the reservoirs from which bacterial plant pathogens emerge. Moreover, because the differences between Pto and its environmental relatives are very small, we now believe that the risk that new highly virulent crop pathogens will emerge from these environments in the future is high. We also found that Pto is frequently exchanged between Europe and North America but not between North and South America. Since P. syringae is present in rain and air masses travel typically west to east but not north to south, we believe that Pto may travel long distance through the atmosphere between Europe and North America and that rain may actually transport this pathogen and cause disease outbreaks. If confirmed, this hypothesis would have a strong impact on agriculture since seed companies are often blamed for outbreaks of bacterial diseases and if rain were confirmed to be a source of P. syringae pathogens, this would need to be considered.

However, we did not only obtain results in regard to dissemination of pathogens, we also obtained new insight into how plants defend themselves against bacterial pathogens. We found that some plant species recognize a region of bacterial flagella that was not previously know to be recognized by plants. Since animals and humans also recognize a similar region of bacterial flagella, comparing how tomatoes recognize bacterial flagella and how humans recognize bacterial flagella should give insight into a very basic mechanism of immunity that in the long term will lead to a better understanding of plant and human immunity. This better understanding could then be translated into improved control of plant diseases and treatment of human diseases.

While performing the research to investigate bacterial plant diseases, four graduate students were trained and obtained their graduate degrees. Over ten undergraduate students were also trained in molecular biology and plant pathology preparing them for their future careers. Also high schools students participated in some of the research and learned about the importance of plant diseases. Moreover, almost 200 undergraduate students were taught about microbial forensics and biosecurity as part of a new course that was developed during this project. These students not only learned about the biology of human, animal, and plant pathogens but they also learned what they can do in their own lives to minimize the spread of new emerging diseases like the bird flu and how they can prepare for such an event and help protect themselves and their friends and families.
